text:
81-87 Liberty Street, east side, between Concord and Tillary Streets, showing the frame building, and the one to the left of it which were demolished in 1923.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Liberty Street, west side, between Liberty Square and Concord Street. In the left center, is Sprague Alley.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, also showing Liberty Square and the Fulton Ave. Elevated Line of the B.M.T.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Liberty Street, west side, between Liberty Square and Concord Street. In the left center, is Sprague Alley.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, also showing Liberty Square and the Fulton Ave. Elevated Line of the B.M.T.

June 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Liberty Street, east side, north from and across Concord Street to High Street. The 6-story structure is the Hudson Brass Works building. All these buildings--among many others--were later razed to make way for a new and wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.
June 2, 1931

P. L. Sperr

(2)
The Hudson Brass building, and others, shortly before they were demolished by the W. P. A.
October 4, 1935

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(3)
The same area, from near below Concord Street. The house in the center is on the north side of the latter street.
March 20, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(1)
Liberty Street, east side, north from and across Concord Street to High Street. The 6-story structure is the Hudson Brass Works building. All these buildings--among many others--were later razed to make way for a new and wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.
June 2, 1931

P. L. Sperr

(2)
The Hudson Brass building, and others, shortly before they were demolished by the W. P. A.
October 4, 1935

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(3)
The same area, from near below Concord Street. The house in the center is on the north side of the latter street.
March 20, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(1)
Liberty Street (right), west side, north from Concord to Nassau Streets. These buildings were later demolished, as part of a W. P. A. project, to make way for the construction of a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. The building on the left extends west to Fulton Street.

P. L. Sperr
June 2, 1931

(2)
The same, showing W. P. A. demolition operations. A portion of the Hastings Hotel is on the right.

1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(1)
Liberty Street (right), west side, north from Concord to Nassau Streets. These buildings were later demolished, as part of a W. P. A. project, to make way for the construction of a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. The building on the left extends west to Fulton Street.

P. L. Sperr
June 2, 1931

(2)
The same, showing W. P. A. demolition operations. A portion of the Hastings Hotel is on the right.

1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(1)
99 (left) to 107 Liberty Street, east side, between Concord and Tillary Streets, near the B. M. T. Fulton Street "El" loop. These buildings--among others--were razed in 1936 by W. P. A. workmen to make way for a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

June 2, 1931

P. L. Sperr

(2),(3)
View 2 shows the buildings as they are being de- molished with others on the east side of Fulton Street, the view being south across the Fulton Street "El."
View 3 shows numbers 103--the Liberty Garage--and No. 101.

March 5, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(1)
99 (left) to 107 Liberty Street, east side, between Concord and Tillary Streets, near the B. M. T. Fulton Street "El" loop. These buildings--among others--were razed in 1936 by W. P. A. workmen to make way for a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

June 2, 1931

P. L. Sperr

(2),(3)
View 2 shows the buildings as they are being de- molished with others on the east side of Fulton Street, the view being south across the Fulton Street "El."
View 3 shows numbers 103--the Liberty Garage--and No. 101.

March 5, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(1)
99 (left) to 107 Liberty Street, east side, between Concord and Tillary Streets, near the B. M. T. Fulton Street "El" loop. These buildings--among others--were razed in 1936 by W. P. A. workmen to make way for a wider approach to the Brooklyn Bridge.

June 2, 1931

P. L. Sperr

(2),(3)
View 2 shows the buildings as they are being de- molished with others on the east side of Fulton Street, the view being south across the Fulton Street "El."
View 3 shows numbers 103--the Liberty Garage--and No. 101.

March 5, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

(1) Liberty Street, north from Concord Street, showing parallel to Liberty Street, the Fulton Street B.M.T. Elevated Line; beyond which is the Towers Garage, at the N.W. corner of Fulton and Middagh Streets. Cutting across the background, is the Brooklyn Bridge.

December 16, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, one block further south.

December 16, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Liberty Street, north from Concord Street, showing parallel to Liberty Street, the Fulton Street B.M.T. Elevated Line; beyond which is the Towers Garage, at the N.W. corner of Fulton and Middagh Streets. Cutting across the background, is the Brooklyn Bridge.
